intro: Dinochloa albociliata, commonly known as the white-fringed grass, is a species of flowering plant native to the eastern United States. It belongs to the Poaceae family, which includes grasses, and is characterized by its slender, erect stems and narrow leaves. The plant produces small, spike-like inflorescences that bear tiny, white or pale green flowers. Dinochloa albociliata typically grows in moist, open habitats such as wet meadows and stream banks. Its botanical features make it an important component of wetland ecosystems.
